Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is to provide partial support for U.S.-based graduate and undergraduate students to attend the Ninth Symposium on Combinatorial Search (SoCS-2016), a scientific conference to be held at Tarrytown, NY from July 6-8, 2016. Combinatorial search is an area of artificial intelligence that deals with systematic trial-and-error exploration of a very large number of alternative solutions to a problem. NSF funding is crucial to support students who would otherwise not be able to attend the symposium. Attending such meetings and presenting their research is an important part of the professional development of students, addressing a critical shortage of highly-skilled computer scientists in the U.S.

SOCS brings together researchers in heuristic search and combinatorial optimization from all areas of artificial intelligence, planning, robotics, constraint programming, operations research, and bioinformatics. The intellectual merit of this activity stems from bringing together in one place at one time researchers from otherwise diverse areas of computer science that both advance the state of the art in heuristic search and/or combinatorial optimization, and also use these tools in their research. The broader impacts come from cross-fertilization of different fields that advance and/or use these tools, by promoting research in this area by providing a small intimate meeting on these topics, a forum for presenting such work, and archival proceedings for publishing work in this area. These latter goals are instrumental to training new researchers in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to support the travel of  U.S.-based undergraduate and graduate students to attend one of a series of annual conferences on combinatorial search.  Combinatorial search is a foundational branch of artificial intelligence that deals with solving problems with very large solution spaces, where the goal is to find an optimal or near-optimal solution.  Example problems include two- or more-person games such as chess, single-agent problems such as Rubik's Cube or road navigation, and constraint satisfaction problems such as crossword puzzles or scheduling of flights, classrooms, manufacturing, etc.  The meetings included the Ninth Symposium on Combinatorial Search held in Tarrytown, NY, July 2016, the Tenth Symposium on Combinatorial Search held in Pittsburgh, PA, June 2017, and the Eleventh Symposium on Combinatorial Search held in Stockholm, Sweden, July 2018. These meetings provide a forum for both professional researchers and students to get together, present and learn about the latest research results, and form collaborations that lead to new research.  For students in particular, it is an invaluable opportunity to interact with, learn from, and be mentored by more senior researchers in the field.  This contributes to the training and professional development of these students into mature professionals in combinatorial search, artificial intelligence, and computer science more generally.


Last Modified: 09/16/2019
Modified by: Richard E Korf

These meetings provide a forum for both professional researchers and students to get together, present and learn about the latest research results, and form collaborations that lead to new research. For students in particular, it is an invaluable opportunity to interact with, learn from, and be mentored by more senior researchers in the field. This contributes to the training and professional development of these students into mature professionals in combinatorial search, artificial intelligence, and computer science more generally.
